snippet: A vast expanse of fossilized trees more than 300 million years old — called a “botanical Pompeii” — could extend as much as 100 miles underneath southern Illinois.
abstract: Scientists are exploring a vast expanse of fossilized trees, possibly extending as much as 100 miles underneath southern Illinois, mapping out an ecosystem from 307 million years ago; vast prehistoric landscape, formed just before the world's first great forests were wiped out by global warming, may shed new light on current climate change.
lead_paragraph: A vast expanse of fossilized trees more than 300 million years old — called a “botanical Pompeii” — could extend as much as 100 miles underneath southern Illinois.

headline.seo: Underground Fossil Forest in Illinois Offers Clues on Climate Change
headline.main: An Underground Fossil Forest Offers Clues on Climate Change
headline.print_headline: An Underground Fossil Forest Offers Clues on Climate Change
